awd_titl_txt: Radio Bursts and Gravity from Parsecs to Gigaparsecs
awd_abstract_narration:
Rapid advances in computational capability have enabled dramatic advances in our understanding of the dynamic sky.  Intensive searches though massive volumes of radio telescope data have revealed "fast radio bursts", highly energetic millisecond flashes of radio emission from far beyond our Galaxy. This research will deepen and broaden our understanding of these transient phenomena.  Using advanced algorithms developed by this research, surveys by the Green Bank Telescope, Arecibo, and others will identify other burst sources, determine their origins, and use them as probes of their extreme environments and the intergalactic medium. The STEM abilities of graduate and undergraduate students will be increased through their involvement in the research. In addition, an inexpensive radio astronomy system capable of detecting celestial radio sources will be developed for tutorials and laboratory exercises for undergraduate and high school students.

The proposed research will provide the observational basis to understand the origin of short duration radio transients such as Fast Radio Bursts (FRBs), probe their population statistics and central engines, and investigate their use as probes of extreme host environments and the intergalactic medium. New algorithms will be developed for single pulse, transient, and pulsar searches, including the implementation of a "finding survey with follow-up" that is robust to selection effects and radio interference. A special area of focus is the Galactic center, where exotic binaries, transient sources, and possible local counterparts to the FRB population may be identified.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The sky at radio wavelengths is full of dynamic phenomena with timescales ranging from years to nanoseconds. Some of the most interesting phenomena relate to pulsars and fast radio bursts. Pulsars are rapidly rotating neutron stars in our Galaxy whose lighthouse beams make them extraordinary laboratories for astrophysics. Fast radio bursts are recently discovered millisecond flashes of radio waves coming from far beyond our Galaxy, whose extraordinary energy output and prolific rate pose a genuine puzzle. These bursts sample tenuous gas in the voids between galaxies, making them unique cosmological probes.

This project focused on observations of bursts and pulses with the world's largest radio telescopes. Large volumes of data were acquired and processed, using software processing pipelines developed and deployed on local machines as well as national supercomputing resources. Specific regions of the sky were targeted, including the core of the Virgo A elliptical galaxy, sites of recent luminous supernova explosions and long gamma-ray bursts, the center of our own Galaxy, and the Galactic plane.

Novel findings included the discovery of extraordinary variability in the pulses from a neutron star with a hyper-strong magnetic field located near our Galactic center, the discovery of new radio pulsars, and the measurement of the masses of neutron stars in binary systems. The frequency sub-structure of fast radio bursts was investigated, and thousands of new bursts were detected from a single repeating burst source over three billion light years away. A new repeating fast radio burst source was identified and localized to its host galaxy four billion light years away, and the presence of a very substantial amount of gas in the host galaxy was inferred along the line of sight. The discovery suggests that the use of fast radio bursts as cosmological probes will require some extra work, since host galaxies can not be assumed to have similar average amounts of gas. Instead, the host galaxy of each burst must be identified and its distance carefully measured.

In addition to these discoveries, comprehensive reviews of the fast radio burst phenomenon were produced. Theoretical models were developed with precessing neutron stars as sources of these bursts. These models successfully explain the observed intermittency in some repeating burst sources. The gas content was measured for the halos of our Galaxy and the host galaxies of fast radio bursts.

Multiple undergraduate students were mentored as part of the project. Some of the work constituted PhD thesis research for two graduate students, who led the analysis and publication of the results for those projects. The results of the work were published in several papers in leading journals. Talks were presented at professional conferences, at amateur astronomy association meetings and planetariums, to classrooms and high school science teachers, and to the general public. Some of these talks are available as podcasts and on public video hosting sites, and have racked up thousands of views.

Finally, the Fast Radio Bursts Community Newsletter was started during the project, with long-term archival online hosting and public access through the Cornell University library. The email newsletter now reaches over 600 subscribers, including most of the active researchers in the field, as well as students, journalists, and interested members of the public.
